Chris, I don't have anything against this change, but if we do it, we need to do the same for joins and perhaps in couple other places. All in all, that's a large amount of work, and scope creep in this context.
Would you mind filing a JIRA for this? You could even tackle it yourself, if you feel like diving into the CS code.

nodes.bodyText:
I don't want to introduce methods that accepts List or Collection of Joiners in this API.
Motivation:

Don't proliferate more combinations of each method (join(List) vs join(vararg) and that for join, ifExists, joinOther, ... and then for Uni, Bi, Tri, ...). Not worth the maintenance burden I'd argue.
We're not really accepting an array - we're accepting a vararg. I don't see use cases at this point in time where users would actually use an array. I do see cases where they would provide 7+ parameters, hence the need for a vararg.

nodes.bodyText: This is handy! I've had need of it a few times, but never thought about this simple solution.

Will notEqual be indexed?
If it's not indexed and therefore syntactic sugar for filtering(), there must be fail-fast if any indexed joiner is behind it (so only notEquals and filtering() can come after it).
If it is indexed, it could be slower is some cases. Should the user be able to choose between indexed vs non-indexed non-equality? Would that choose be using notEquals() vs filtering(a!=b)?

All in all, the notEquals raises a red flag of "when in doubt, leave it out" for me, especially due to that last question, until we discuss it properly and/or know more about how users use ConstraintStreams. Wdyt?

In Drools, NOT_EQUAL is an implemented index type, so CS-D behaves the same for EQUAL as for NOT_EQUAL.
There is no Bavet support for NOT_EQUAL and it will throw an exception if you try to use it.
There is no way to leave this out, as otherwise I can't have ifExistsOther(). That requires notEqual(). (Alternatively, a filter with poor performance.)
Similar to the javadoc of that filter() method, this javadoc should mention the lack of indexing.
In fact, the reason why I reference that other Javadoc is to avoid having to say this everywhere. That Javadoc says it, and this Javadoc says "same semantics".
always start with "never null" or "sometimes null". (in this case never null)

nodes.bodyText:
There is a join(Class<B>, joiners) and a join(Uni<B>, joiners).
Do both support filtering() joiners now? Isn't this new code below here duplicated between them?
It feels to me like we want to extract these new lines below into a separate non-public method if possible.

This is an interface and Java 8, so there are no non-public methods.
Yes, all the join() methods support filtering(). In fact, filtering() is converted to join().filter(), so the JoinStream never even gets to see that particular joiner.

Good that the JoinStream never sees that partical joiner.
I am just wondering - if both join(Class) and join(Stream) handle the FilteringJoiner-extraction, do they duplicate the code below? If so, can we de-duplicate it by letting this one delegate to the Stream one?
"Only found indexing joiners." is not a sentence, don't end with "."
Style issue is still here: remove the "." at the end in the comment because it's not a sentance
I partially agree - with the order, not with avoiding the hasAFilter variable, which in my opinion rather adds to readability.

Don't create this "always true" predicate:

If there is no filtering, don't call filter().
If there is only 1 filter, let's say Foo::isReady, don't create a wrapper predicate of an always true predicate combined with foo.isReady(), just use `Foo::isReady``directly.
Same reasoning for 2 filters (don't make it 3)
...

Motivation:

performance (especially with the extra filter() call for those that don't use it, it currently will cause non-trivial perf degredation in Bavet that creates tuples for filters)
node sharing (same lambda recognition)

join(Class) and join(Class, joiner) are very commonly used, so they don't use "As defined by" in the javadocs (the extra click might have some people not read it). They are an exception, because using "as defined by" reduces maintenance.
I'd argue that "joinOther(Class)" can use "As defined by join(Class)" and then something like "With the additional joiner than they are not equal" (but better written).
Same for "joinOther(Class, Joiner)" => "As defined by join(Class, Joiner) with the additional joiner than they are not equal"
But indeed for joinOther(Class, Joiner, Joiner) and more, I 'd keep using "As defined by joinOther(Class, Joiner, Joiner)" (so no need of "with the additional ..." because it references joinOther, not join).
Motivation: users that use "joinOther" are likely already to know "join", so it's even better for them (= quicker to understand) if we say "whatever you already know from join() plus they are not equal"

If nonEquals is indexed, does this merge make sure that if we do:
joinOther(Foo.class, equal(getType), filtering(a, b -> a.getAge * b.getAge == 42))
it is syntactic sugar for:
join(Foo.class, equal(getType), notEqual(), filtering(a, b -> a.getAge * b.getAge == 42))
So the first joiner remained the first joiner, but the second joiner became third joiner, because it's the first non-indexed joiner.
Ordering of joiners is never changed. When notEqual() is added by the joinOther() statement, it as added as the first joiner.

The order of joiners gets changed here:
joinOther(Foo.class, x, y z) should be join(Foo.class, x, y, z, notEquals())
That's currently not the case.
Motivation: The order of the joiners can heavily affect performance, so we must respect the user's order such that they can tweak it.

I strongly disagree.
When using joinOther(), your implicit assumption is that you'll be getting only those that are not equal. Therefore, the notEqual() joiner must come first.
(I agree on the performance point. But the fact that you'll get this joiner with joinOther is just assumed - if you don't want this joiner, call join() and do whatever you wish.)

Just noticed (not a problem in this PR). This joinerId is not an ID, it's an index, for CombinedBiJoiners. That variable should be renamed to joinerIndex or just index (I 'd say the latter). Again, doesn't need to happen in this PR.
What the different between an ID and and index?
ID's have gaps, as elements get deleted. Examples of ID's: 0, 1, 2, 4, 7
Indexes don't have gaps, they would naturally change if elements get deleted (ussually they won't): Examples of index: 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5
